issues.description: In the problem statement Part 3 description (lines ~109-111) the text says feedAllAnimals() should call getFeedingSound() on each animal, but everywhere else (UML, task descriptions, and the solution/template code) the abstract method is named messageOnFeed(). This name mismatch in the specification can confuse students about which method they must implement and call (messageOnFeed() vs. getFeedingSound()), and could lead to implementations that do not match the tests or the provided solution.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the method name consistent across the problem statement, UML, template, and solution. Replace the reference to getFeedingSound() in Part 3 with messageOnFeed() (or vice versa, but consistently) and update any explanatory text to use the same method name. This ensures students know to implement and call messageOnFeed() as defined in the UML and solution.

issues.description: The problem statement refers to a feeding-sound method using the name getFeedingSound() (in the per-animal description and the song template), while the UML, template hints, and the solution implementation use the method name messageOnFeed(). This creates a naming mismatch for the same conceptual operation (the animal's feeding sound) and may cause students to implement the wrong method name or be confused when mapping the textual song specification to the provided/required code.
issues.suggested_fix: Unify the method name across all artifacts. Preferred fix: replace all occurrences of getFeedingSound() in the problem statement (song template and animal descriptions) with messageOnFeed() so the textual requirements match the UML, template hints, and solution. Alternatively, if you prefer getFeedingSound(), rename the abstract method in Animal and all implementations to getFeedingSound() and update template/solution accordingly. Ensure the problem text and code use the same identifier to avoid student confusion.
